comments.text:
+Michael Vander Wal In Fox's graph 7,000,000 is 8 unit lines up the y-axis. 
This means 875,000 people per unit line. The y-axis at 3 unit lines up is 
visually representative of 2,625,000 people. This leaves us with a visual 
discrepancy of 3,375,000 people. This is one of the most basic forms of 
visually manipulating data within a graph. It's an easy way to give 
misleading information without actually lying. This graph is digital, which 
means you have to explicitly change the graphic to match what they are 
displaying (they aren't just plugging values into a graph application, 
otherwise it would be proportional). To think that this was a mistake is 
foolish.

Now we can make this graph "more accurate" and come up with a better lie by 
assuming that the 5 unit lines between 6,000,000 and 7,000,000 are 200,000 
people each. Then when we display the graph a 2nd time, we put 5,400,000 at 
the base of the graph and say "Oops, we forgot to tell you where the graph 
started!"

You should always take information provided by media outlets with a grain 
of salt. It is shameful that there were people out there that saw this 
graph and bought into the manipulation.

comments.text:
The Young Turks did the same thing in many of the charts they showed, 
including in the video titled "Want To Scare Your Friends? Show Them This 
Chart" where they showed a chart showing increases in Carbon Dioxide from 
310 ppm to 400 ppm but left out the bottom 300 ppm from the chart to 
emphasize the difference over time.  Had they shown the chart to scale and 
starting at zero the line would have been more flat and the change over 
time would have appeared less exaggerated.  The purpose of Fox's chart was 
also to show difference, in this case between the expected and current 
Obamacare enrollment through the exchanges.  The Fox chart is much easier 
simpler and therefore easier to mock, but the basic practice is common, 
including in academic papers, and is not considered misleading as long as 
the scale is clearly labeled.﻿
